Discussão 



93 

 

Discussão 

 

O sucesso da estabilidade primária após a instalação de um implante depende basicamente 

da interação entre os parâmetros de quantidade e qualidade da base óssea em que este é instalado, 

da macro-estrutura do implante e da técnica cirúrgica empregada5,6,12-14. 

Vários fabricantes têm se empenhado em desenvolver formatos diversos de implantes com 

a finalidade de proporcionar uma estabilidade primária mais previsível em condições ósseas 

adversas16. Dentro do nosso conhecimento, não existem estudos comparativos entre implantes 

controlando os fatores de variabilidade óssea, analisando e correlacionando testes por imagens 

(microtomográficas e histomorfométicas), a resultados de avaliações biomecânicas. Desse modo, 

o presente trabalho propôs-se a testar cinco tipos diferentes de implantes em um sistema de bases 

ósseas padronizadas de alta e baixa densidades  

A macro-estrutura de um implante pode influenciar a interface osso-implante, sendo este 

um dos parâmetros importantes para se atingir a estabilidade primária15,18,73. Implantes de desenhos 

variados, instalados em diferentes bases ósseas, atingem diferentes graus de estabilidade, o que 

pode determinar o seu desempenho clínico futuro6,28,59,70,73. Vários estudos têm demonstrado 

relação entre o design do implante e a osseointegração21,33,34,74,75. O formato cônico dos implantes 

foi originalmente destinado a aumentar o contato osso-implante (BIC), proporcionando uma maior 

compactação no tecido ósseo adjacente, maximizando o torque de inserção, frequência de 

ressonância e a sua resistência ao arrancamento5,20,22,32. Neste estudo foram utilizados implantes 

auto-rosqueáveis de formato cônico (Drive), cilíndrico cônico (Alvim, Ankylos e Xive) e 

cilíndrico (Straumann Bone Level), com a finalidade de observar a compactação da estrutura óssea 

adjacente e a estabilidade primária obtida em diferentes densidades ósseas.  

Os formatos das roscas dos implantes também influenciam na estabilidade primária, pelo 

aumento da área de contato osso-implante e pela distribuição das cargas biomecânicas18,22,74. 

Encontram-se disponíveis no mercado os formatos de rosca triangular (“V”), quadrado, trapezoidal 

e suas variações. As roscas no formato triangular possuem um cisalhamento semelhante às de 

formato trapezoidal e 10 vezes superior em comparação com as roscas quadradas. A área de 

superfície otimizada que estas roscas de formato quadrado possuem é ótima para transmissão de 

cargas intrusivas e compressivas que resultam em tensão óssea menor. Já as roscas trapezoidais 

têm maior resistência à carga de tração69,76. Chang et al.77, avaliaram o padrão de 



94 

 

micromovimentos na interface do implante com o osso circundante, com diferentes designs de 

rosca (trapezoidal, quadrado e padrão de rosca -V) sob carga imediata axial de 300 N. Os resultados 

revelaram que todos os micromovimentos foram localizados perto da interface de osso-implante e 

o perfil de rosca quadrada obteve valores mais favoráveis aos micromovimentos, demonstrando 

assim a sua superioridade para estes casos. O presente estudo concorda com estes resultados, pois 

os implantes Alvim, Drive e Ankylos, que apresentam variações de roscas no formato quadrado, 

foram superiores em diversos parâmetros analisados para avaliar a estabilidade primária. 

A variação de três parâmetros da geometria da rosca pode modificar a área de superfície 

funcional por unidade de comprimento do implante: a distância entre as roscas (passo de rosca), o 

formato e a profundidade das roscas69. A distância entre as roscas, ou passo da rosca, é definida 

como a quantidade de roscas por unidade de comprimento. Quanto menor é o passo, maior é a 

quantidade de roscas no corpo de implante, o que significa uma maior área de contato osso-

implante18,74. Recentemente foram introduzidos no mercado os conceitos de “dupla-rosca” e 

“tripla-rosca”, que têm sido associados a uma maior rapidez e menor trauma na inserção. No 

presente estudo, os implantes Alvim CM apresentam roscas duplas, os implantes Ankylos 

apresentam roscas progressivas, e os implantes Drive CM, roscas duplas e progressivas.  

Para avaliar a influência da biomecânica de implantes inseridos em tecido ósseo de 

diferentes densidades, métodos como torque de inserção, frequência de ressonância e teste de 

arrancamento são os mais utilizados nas áreas de cirurgia ortopédica e odontologia22. O valor do 

torque de inserção (IT) é o parâmetro clínico mais utilizado pelos cirurgiões para medir a 

estabilidade primária. Este IT é observado através da resistência de rotação entre o tecido ósseo e 

as roscas do implante durante a inserção, sendo recomendado para o uso de cargas imediatas um 

valor mínimo de 35 N.cm5,32. 

Com relação à análise de torque de inserção realizada no presente estudo, foram observadas 

diferenças estatisticamente significantes nas diferentes bases ósseas. Esses resultados corroboram 

com os achados na literatura, que enfatizam que diferentes áreas de contato entre o osso e o 

implante afetam a estabilidade primária, e esta área é influenciada por meio da macro-estrutura do 

implante e formato de suas roscas. Essa influência foi observada por Lozano-Carrascal et al.15, que 

avaliaram a relação da macro-estrutura dos implantes com a estabilidade primária por meio do 

torque de inserção (IT) e da análise de frequência de ressonância (RFA) em diferentes bases ósseas. 

Para isso, utilizaram um total de 47 implantes divididos em dois grupos: grupo teste (GT): 22 



95 

 

implantes cônicos Mis®Seven (MIS®, Medicalimplants System, Israel); grupo controle (GC): 25 

implantes cilíndricos Astra® OsseoSpeed (Astra Tech Implant System, Dentsply, Mölndal, 

Suécia). A estabilidade primária do implante foi medida no momento da instalação do implante, 

registrando valores de IT e valores de RFA. Na mandíbula, no GT a média ± desvio padrão dos 

valores de ISQ foram de 71,67 ± 5,16, e para o GC de 57,15 ± 4,83 (p = 0,01). A média± desvio 

padrão dos valores de IT foi de 46,67 ± 6,85 N.cm para GT e 35,77 ± 6,72 N.cm para o GC (p = 

0,01). Na maxila, a média de ISQ foi de 67,2 ± 4,42 para os implantes cônicos (GT) e 49,17 ± 

15,30 para implantes cilíndricos (GC) (p = 0,01). A média de IT no GT foi de 41,5 ± 6,26 N.cm e 

para o GC de 39,17 ± 6,34 N.cm (p> 0,05). Com isso, concluiu-se que: os implantes de formato 

cônico alcançaram maior estabilidade primária que os implantes cilíndricos; os implantes 

instalados em diferentes bases ósseas tiveram graus de estabilidade diferentes e os implantes 

cônicos instalados na mandíbula (osso de alta densidade) tiveram valores mais elevados de IT e 

RFA que os instalados na maxila (osso de baixa densidade). Dantas et al.70, fazem uma análise 

comparativa da estabilidade inicial de dois diferentes tipos de implantes (e-Fix HE e e-Fix HE 

Silver), utilizando cilindros ósseos padronizados de origem suína, de alta e baixa densidades, em 

modelo in vitro, através de ensaios biomecânicos e de imagens. Os autores observaram, ao analisar 

o IT, que os grupos de alta densidade também apresentaram resultados numericamente superiores 

aos implantes instalados em bases ósseas de alta densidade. O presente estudo corrobora estas 

observações, pois os maiores valores de IT e de RFA foram encontrados em cilindros ósseos de 

alta densidade. Além disso, os formatos de implantes cônico e cilíndrico-cônico, ambos com roscas 

quadradas, foram superiores em relação a este quesito: os implantes do G4 (IT alta densidade: 

38,18 ± 2,75 N.cm e IT baixa densidade: 21 ± 9,43 N.cm; RFA alta densidade: 69,75 ± 1,78 ISQ 

e RFA baixa densidade: 63,75 ± 3,02 ISQ) e os do G5 (TI alta densidade: 47,66 ± 8,51 N.cm e IT 

baixa densidade: 19,46 ± 2,93 N.cm; RFA alta densidade: 66,50 ± 2,83 ISQ e RFA baixa 

densidade: 61,20 ± 3,18 ISQ) apresentaram, em ambas as bases ósseas, valores estatisticamente 

superiores aos demais grupos. 

A avaliação do coeficiente de estabilidade do implante (ISQ) através da análise de 

frequência de ressonância (RFA) é o método não invasivo mais utilizado para avaliar a estabilidade 

do conjunto implante/base óssea. Ramakrishna e Nayar78 relataram que, em geral, valores de 50 a 

60 ISQ são mais vistos em osso mais trabecular, e valores de 60 a 80 ISQ são típicos de osso mais 

denso. Javed e Romanos79, entretanto, relatam que, até a data, não havia nenhum estudo clínico 



96 

 

que comprovasse qual seria o valor ideal de RFA no qual os implantes sobreviveriam a longo 

prazo, nem o valor de RFA mínimo necessário para que os implantes submetidos à carga imediata 

tivessem sucesso. No entanto, Rodrigo et al.80, afirmaram que nenhum dos implantes com valores 

acima de 60 ISQ foram perdidos, enquanto que 19% dos implantes com valores menores que 60 

ISQ tiveram falha no tratamento. Os resultados do presente estudo apresentaram valores de ISQ 

superiores a 60 para todos os grupos, em ambas as bases ósseas, sendo que o G4 (69,75 ± 1,78 na 

alta densidade e na baixa densidade de 63,75 ± 3,02) apresentou resultados numéricos e 

estatisticamente superiores, tanto na alta como na baixa densidade. 

Turkyilmaz et al.81, avaliaram a correlação entre a qualidade óssea e parâmetros de 

estabilidade de implantes por meio de tomografia computadorizada (CT), torque de inserção (IT) 

e frequência de ressonância (RFA). Observaram que os valores médios dos implantes nos 

parâmetros de densidade óssea, torque de inserção e RFA foram de 152 ± 264 HU, 41,7 ± 6 N.cm 

e 69,7 ± 9 ISQ, respectivamente. Estatisticamente foram encontradas correlações significativas 

entre a densidade óssea e valores de torque de inserção, densidade óssea e valores de ISQ e torque 

de inserção e os valores do ISQ. No entanto, Degidi et al.82, ao avaliar a correlação da estabilidade 

de implantes (Xive) nestes mesmos parâmetros, relataram não haver previsão de estabilidade 

suficiente para evitar erros ao usar uma técnica de carga imediata; além disso, observaram uma 

baixa correlação entre IT e a RFA (0,247, teste de Correlação de Spearman), mostrando assim que 

as duas variáveis são praticamente independentes, sugerindo que RFA e IT representam duas 

características diferentes de estabilidade primária, com a primeira indicando a resistência à carga 

de flexão, e a segundo indicando a resistência às forças de cisalhamento. Os resultados do presente 

trabalho, também analisando os parâmetros de RFA e IT em diferentes implantes instalados em 

bases ósseas de alta e baixa densidade, demonstraram melhores valores para os mesmos grupos 

(G4 IT alta densidade: 38,18 ± 2,75 N.cm e IT baixa densidade: 21 ± 9,43 N.cm; RFA alta 

densidade: 69,75 ± 1,78 ISQ e RFA baixa densidade: 63,75 ± 3,02 ISQ; e o G5 IT alta densidade: 

47,66 ± 8,51 N.cm e IT baixa densidade: 19,46 ± 2,93 N.cm; RFA alta densidade: 66,50 ± 2,83 

ISQ e RFA baixa densidade: 61,20 ± 3,18 ISQ) em ambos os testes nas duas bases ósseas. Assim, 

embora não tenham sido realizados testes de correlação, parece haver uma concordância de 

resultados para estes dois parâmetros. 

Materiais ósseos artificiais sintéticos têm sido considerados boas alternativas para 

realização de testes mecânicos, especialmente para avaliação da estabilidade primária. No presente 



97 

 

estudo, um material sintético foi escolhido para ser avaliado comparativamente às bases ósseas 

padronizadas. De acordo com a American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM)72, as 

propriedades de uniformidade e consistência do poliuretano rígido fazem deste um material ideal 

para realização de testes biomecânicos com implantes. Liu et al.57, observaram uma correlação 

positiva entre os valores de IT com a densidade óssea e espessura do osso cortical, em osso 

artificial. Neste estudo, ao avaliar este mesmo teste nos blocos de poliuretano, observou-se 

diferença estatisticamente significante nos Grupos: G6 (25,06 ± 3,12 N.cm) e o G10 (35,06 ± 8,70 

N.cm); G7 (21,55 ± 1,83 N.cm) e o G10 (35,06 ± 8,70 N.cm), nos blocos de baixa densidade. Nos 

blocos de alta densidade não foi observada diferença estatística entre os grupos, apesar de valores 

elevados em todos eles (acima de 60 N.cm). Com relação aos grupos de baixa densidade, somente 

o G10 apresentou resultados superiores a 35 N.cm.  

Com relação à análise de frequência de ressonância (RFA) realizada nos blocos de 

poliuretano no presente estudo, ambas as bases ósseas artificiais apresentaram valores de ISQ 

maiores que 60, com maiores valores nas bases de alta densidade. Os implantes tiveram resultados 

homogêneos na mesma base óssea, não sendo observada diferença estatisticamente significante 

em nenhum dos grupos. Alguns autores observaram uma correlação positiva entre os valores de 

ISQ e IT com a densidade óssea e espessura do osso cortical4, porém em outros estudos essa 

correlação não foi observada, relatando ainda que o RFA não parece ser adequado como único 

método de avaliação da estabilidade6,47. O presente trabalho corrobora estes achados, pois em 

blocos de poliuretano a RFA não foi capaz de apontar diferenças entre os grupos experimentais. 

O ensaio de arrancamento (PS) é outra possibilidade de análise mecãnica da estabilidade 

primária de implantes, comparando a resistência ao arrancamento de diferentes dos implantes6,57. 

Kim et al.83, estudaram a relação da resistência ao arrancamento de diferentes implantes inseridos 

em diferentes densidades ósseas. Para tal, utilizaram implantes cônico e cilíndrico e com diversas 

conformidades de roscas (triangular (“V”), quadrado, trapezoidal). Com isso, concluíram que os 

implantes de roscas quadradas tiveram menor resistência ao arrancamento que os implantes de 

roscas – V, independente da densidade óssea (p<0,5). No presente estudo, os implantes Bone Level 

(G8), instalados em ambas as bases ósseas, apresentaram maior resistência ao arrancamento (G8 

alta: 944,34 ± 36,81 Newtons; G8 baixa: 339,81 ± 15,92 Newtons). Este grupo apresentou 

diferenças estatisticamente significantes quando comparados os outros implantes na mesma base 

óssea de alta densidade (G10 alta: 525,04 ± 55,93; G7 alta: 710,73 ± 76,04 e G6: 636,72 ± 73,45) 



98 

 

e aos implantes em bases ósseas de baixa densidade (G6: 220,03 ± 15,84 e G7: 240,64 ± 4,63). 

Desse modo, provavelmente devido a sua conformidade de rosca (triangular - “V”), tenha 

ocasionado uma maior retenção no momento de arrancamento, quando comparado aos demais 

implantes. 

Oliscovicz et al.22, avaliaram, através de ensaios biomecânicos (IT e PS), a influência da 

estabilidade primária de implantes de formatos e tratamentos diferentes (Master Porous, Master 

Screw, Conect AR, Conect Cônico) inseridos em diversos substratos ósseos. Com relação à 

resistência ao arrancamento (PS), os autores observaram que os implantes inseridos no osso suíno 

e no poliuretano Synbone não apresentaram diferença estatística entre todos os tipos de implantes, 

porém no poliuretano Nacional de 40 PCF (alta densidade), os implantes cônicos tiveram um 

resultado inferior aos outros (491,68 ± 75,91 N), resultado este que concorda com os obtidos no 

presente estudo, no qual o G10 apresentou os menores valores nesta base. Na densidade de 20 PCF 

(baixa densidade), os implantes cônicos tiveram a segunda maior média (206,57 ± 31,51 N), porém 

sem diferença estatística, o que também ocorreu no presente estudo.  

A histomorfometria é um dos métodos para avaliar a arquitetura do osso cortical e 

trabecular, permitindo qualificar e quantificar de forma segura as estruturas ósseas, sendo esta 

técnica classificada por muito tempo como o “padrão-ouro”44,45,47. No presente estudo, após 

preparo histológico, cada imagem do implante foi captada a partir das lâminas pré confeccionadas. 

A partir da captura das imagens foram determinados 4 níveis para a avaliação histomorfométrica: 

Nível1) Densidade óssea entre as roscas; Nível 2) Densidade óssea das áreas imediatamente 

adjacentes as roscas; Nível 3) Densidade óssea distante aos implantes e Nível 4) Densidade óssea 

na região apical ao implante. Também foram determinadas as porcentagens de contato osso-

implante (BIC). Em relação à análise da densidade óssea, foram avaliados os percentuais (%) de 

trabécula óssea e espaço medular nas áreas avaliadas. Constatou-se que entre as roscas (N1) houve 

um maior percentual de trabéculas quando comparadas às áreas distantes das roscas (N3) e 

apicalmente ao implante (N4), para todos os grupos de alta densidade, sendo estatisticamente 

significante nos grupos G2, G3, G4 e G5. Na área imediatamente adjacente às roscas (N2) foi 

observado valores numéricos ligeiramente menores que no N1, demonstrando assim uma 

propagação da condensação óssea exercida pelo desenho do implante durante sua inserção, 

melhorando a densidade óssea entre as roscas na área imediatamente áreas adjacente, e 

consequentemente promovendo uma maior estabilidade inicial, o que concorda com o postulado 



99 

 

por Hsu et al.58. Com relação aos achados no N3, provavelmente essa propagação da condensação 

não chegue à essas áreas, não afetando as trabéculas à distância. No osso de baixa densidade, 

também houve uma tendência à diminuição numérica, porém mais gradual que na base óssea de 

alta densidade, sendo esses resultados mais evidentes na comparação entre N4 (apical) e N1 (intra-

rosca). Constatou-se ainda que no G1, G4 e G5 houve, numericamente, maior densidade na área 

logo após às roscas (N2), comparado aos valores entre as roscas (N1). Além disso, no G1, tanto na 

alta como na baixa densidade, foi observado esse aumento numérico no N2. Provavelmente isso 

se deveu ao fato de que, no osso de baixa densidade, durante a perfuração com a última broca e a 

inserção do implante, tenha havido uma desorganização das trabéculas, ocorrendo menor 

compactação na área intra-rosca. 

A estabilidade do implante é teoricamente afetada pela área do contato osso-implante 

(BIC), havendo maior estabilidade quando há uma maior quantidade de osso em contato com o 

implante, resultando em uma maior resistência nesta interface57. As variadas modificações no 

desenho do implante têm a finalidade de aumentar a área de superfície em contato com o osso15. 

Neste estudo foi verificado que o G2, tanto na alta densidade como na baixa densidade, demonstrou 

maior quantidade, numericamente e estatisticamente, de osso em contato com o implante. Estudos 

mostram uma correlação entre quantidade e profundidade das roscas com variáveis que afetam e 

maximizam o contato osso-implante22,23. Outros estudos ainda afirmam que implantes com espiras 

menos profundas e menos espaço entre si podem interferir na estabilidade primária avaliada 

através do IT28,86. No G4 foi observado um dos menores valores de contato osso-implante em 

ambas as bases ósseas achados estes que não corroboram os resultados dos ensaios biomecânicos, 

pois tanto o G4 como o G5 apresentaram maiores valores de IT e RFA, nos testes em osso suíno, 

quando comparados aos outros grupos. Desse modo, talvez o plano bidimensional da avaliação 

histomorfométrica não seja suficientemente preciso para avaliar a situação tridimensional do 

implante na base óssea. 

A utilização de imagens de alta resolução, obtidas através de microtomografia 

computadorizada (Micro-CT), para avaliar a morfologia do osso trabecular e cortical em espécimes 

animais e humanos tem crescido imensamente. É uma técnica não destrutiva que reconstrói 

amostras na escala microtomográfica e obtém informações sobre sua geometria tridimensional e 

propriedades do material45,49. No presente estudo a avaliação tomográfica tridimensional foi 

realizada em quatro níveis ósseos distintos (osso na região entre as roscas, imediatamente 



100 

 

adjacente a estas, distando de 0,5 a 1,5 mm destas e apicalmente ao implante), e em dois tempos 

(pré e pós-inserção do implante), objetivando avaliar o efeito da inserção dos cinco tipos de 

implantes nas bases ósseas de baixa e alta densidades.  

A análise das diferenças pós - pré inserção dos implantes para o parâmetro de densidade 

óssea tridimensional (BV/TV) mostrou uma maior condensação entre as roscas (N1), comparada 

à área distante das roscas (N3), para todos os grupos em ambas as densidades ósseas. A análise 

entre grupos demonstrou que todos os implantes instalados nas bases ósseas de baixa densidade 

tiveram uma maior condensação percentual (aumento de BV/TV), numericamente e 

estatisticamente, que os implantes instalados na alta densidade, sendo este efeito mais evidente no 

N1 e havendo uma tendência de redução da condensação até o N3. Resultados semelhantes 

também foram observados em relação às reduções no parâmetro tomográfico de separação 

trabecular (Tb.Sp). Estes resultados concordam com os achados de Karg et al.47, que ao analisar a 

relação entre a estabilidade primária, correlacionando com os parâmetros estruturais do osso 

trabecular por meio de tomografia computadorizada (CBCT), observaram que uma correlação 

positiva com os parâmetros estruturais do osso trabecular (BV/TV, BV, BS, BSD, Tb.Th, Tb.N, 

FD e BS/BV) (p<0,01), e correlação negativas com outros parâmetros microestruturais (Tb.Sp, 

Tb.Pf e SMI). Há ainda concordância com os resultados de Dantas et al.70, que avaliando os 

mesmos parâmetros estruturais do presente estudo, observaram a mesma tendência de condensação 

nos dois parâmetros correlacionados (evidenciada por aumento de BV/TV e diminuição de Th.Sp). 

A avaliação da diferença da porosidade total, pós e pré-inserção dos implantes, mostrou 

que quanto maior foi a condensação pós-inserção dos implantes, houve maior quantidade de Poros 

Fechados (Po.Cl), menor quantidade de Poros Abertos (Po.Op), e uma redução na Porosidade Total 

(Po.Tot). Assim, para Po.Cl, os resultados mais significantes para alta densidade foram obtidos 

pelos G4 e G5, enquanto para baixa densidade G2 e G5 apresentaram melhores resultados. No 

parâmetro Po.Op a redução foi mais evidente nos grupos G4 e G5 na alta densidade, e no G3 na 

baixa densidade. Para o parâmetro Po.Tot os grupos foram o G4 e G5 mostraram as maiores 

reduções após a inserção do implante, tanto nas bases de alta e baixa densidades ósseas. 

A análise dos parâmetros microtomográficos mostrou uma influência dos implantes na 

alteração da estrutura óssea até o nível 2 de avaliação (até 0,5 mm de distância do final das roscas), 

resultando em aumento da condensação óssea, diminuição da separação trabecular e da porosidade. 

A análise das áreas ósseas mais distantes ao implante (N3) mostrou uma baixa propagação da 



101 

 

condensação óssea quando comparada aos outros níveis (N1, N2 e N4). Além disso, houve 

aumento da densidade óssea na região apical (N4), o que pode ser devido à técnica de preparação 

do leito receptor, tendo havido a compressão da estrutura óssea pelo movimento axial do implante. 

Este achado pode ser particularmente importante para implantes instalados em bases ósseas de 

baixa densidade: a compactação óssea apical pode auxiliar na ancoragem dos implantes, 

aumentando a estabilidade inicial. Blitz et al.84, demonstraram por meio de um estudo em tíbia de 

ratos, que é possível visualizar e quantificar a porosidade da cortical óssea em ratos usando Micro-

CT, e os autores puderam validar seus resultados comparando com a análise histológica 

convencional. O presente estudo corrobora este achado na literatura, observando relação entre 

histomorfometria 2D convencional e análise 3D por meio de Micro-CT, especialmente para os 

parâmetros BV/TV, Tb.SP, Po.Cl, Po.Op e Po.Tot.  

Embora a estabilidade do implante primário tenha sido extensivamente investigada em 

relação à densidade óssea trabecular e espessura do osso cortical, poucos estudos examinaram a 

relação entre a estabilidade do implante e microestrutura do osso trabecular47. Alguns estudos 

mostram que há correlação entre IT na instalação do implante, contato osso-implante (BIC) e 

qualidade óssea57,59. A densidade óssea, de acordo com a CT, CBTC e Micro-CT, teve correlação 

significativa com os valores de IT e RFA81,85. Quanto maior for o CBTC, maior é a força máxima 

de arrancamento67. Foi observada também correlação entre a RFA e IT e parâmetros 

morfológicos51. Porém, Kang et al.47, revelaram que não há correlação entre esses parâmetros, 

afirmando que a RFA, como único método de avaliação da estabilidade primaria, não parece ser 

adequada. O presente estudo mostrou uma coerência dos resultados biomecânicos com as análises 

de imagem (subtração, histológica e microtomográfica), demonstrando melhores resultados nos 

implantes Alvim CM e Drive CM, em ambas as bases ósseas. Os resultados histológicos 

confirmaram os resultados obtidos por análise de microtomografia computadorizada, 

demonstrando assim a validade do método de análise por imagem. 



102 

 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

Conclusão 



103 

 

Conclusão 
 

De acordos os resultados obtidos neste estudo, pode-se concluir que: 

 

? A densidade óssea avaliada pelos métodos de imagem (radiografia convencional, subtração 

de imagem, microtomografia computadorizada e histomorfometria) correlacionaram-se 

aos valores de torque de inserção, frequência de ressonância e resistência ao arrancamento, 

demonstrando influência na estabilidade primária. 

 

? Os resultados biomecânicos (IT, RFA e PS) demonstraram coerência com as análises de 

imagem, apresentando melhores resultados para os implantes Alvim e principalmente para 

o Drive CM, implantes segundo o fabricante desenhados e indicados para a maximização 

de estabilidade primária. Dentre os implantes de uso geral, indicados pelo fabricante para 

uso em todas as áreas/tipos de osso, o implante Ankylos apresentou melhores resultados. 

 

? Os resultados histomorfométricos confirmaram os resultados obtidos pela análise 

microtomográfica, demonstrando assim a validade do método 3D de análise por imagem. 

 

? A microtomografia computadorizada pode ser considerada como “padrão ouro”, por ser 

um método mais sensível para delinear novos parâmetros de quantificação da 

microestrutura trabecular, avaliando a interação osso-implante detalhadamente em três 

dimensões.

Apêndice - Artigo em Inglês I 

 

Assessment of primary stability of five different implants inserted in standardized bone 

bases. Histomorphometric and Microtomographic analyses. 

 

Carolina Delmondes Freitas Dantas, Graduate student of Periodontology * 

Arthur Belém Novaes Jr, Chairman of Periodontology * 

Adriana Almeida, Graduate student of Oral Biology 

Danilo Maeda Reino, Graduate student of Periodontology * 

Michel Messora, Professor of Periodontology *

* Department of Traumatology, Bucco-Maxillo-Facial Surgery and Periodontology, School of 

Dentistry of Ribeirão Preto, University of São Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil 

** Department of Oral Rehabilitation, School of Dentistry of Ribeirão Preto, University of São 

Paulo, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil

Sérgio Luis Scombatti de Souza 

Faculdade de Odontologia de Ribeirão Preto - USP, Departamento de CTBMF e Periodontia, Av. 

do Café s/n, 14040-904, Ribeirão Preto, SP, Brazil.  

E-mail: scombati@forp.usp.br 

 

Abstract 

Primary stability, post-implant insertion, is key to the application of immediate load, and is an 

increasingly desirable clinical situation by professionals and patients. The aim of this study was to 

evaluate the primary stability of five different implants inserted in standardized bone bases of 

porcine bone and polyurethane blocks (in vitro models), by means of mechanical tests and image 

analysis (microtomographic e histomorphometric). Digital radiographs were taken in order to 

certify and standardize the porcine bone cylinders, determining high- and low-density bone 

cylinders. After the certification, computed microtomographies of the bone cylinders for the three-

dimensional analysis of images prior to implant insertion were taken, assessing the following 

parameters: BV/TV; Tb.Sp and Po.Tot. in 3 bone levels (L1- bone volume internal to the threads; 

L2– 0 to 0.5mm from the end of threads; L3 - 0.5mm to 1.5mm from the end of threads, and L4 – 

0 to 0.5mm apical to implant), post- and pre-implant insertion assessment. Subsequently, 50 

http://www.perioforp.com.br/ptBR/scombati@forp.usp.br


114 

 

implants of five different models were selected, divided in five groups with ten implants each: 

Group 1 (G1): Xive Plus implants inserted in bone cylinders of high density (n=5) and low density 

(n=5); Group 2 (G2): Ankylos implants inserted in bone cylinders of high density (n=5) and low 

density (n=5); Group 3 (G3): Bone Level implants inserted in bone cylinders of high density (n=5) 

and low density (n=5); Group 4 (G4): AlvimCM inserted in bone cylinders of high density (n=5) 

and low density (n=5); Group 5 (G5): DriveCM inserted in bone cylinders of high density (n=5) 

and low density (n=5). After implant insertion, they were analyzed as to insertion torque (IT) and 

resonance frequency (RFA). According to the post- and pre-implant insertion results for all the 

parameters assessed by MicroCT, there were statistically significant differences especially for G4 

(AlvimCM) and G5 (DriveCM) when compared to the other groups. The histomorphometric 

analysis showed higher bone compression and Bone-Implant Contact (BIC) values for G2 

(Ankylos), G4 (AlvimCM) and G5 (DriveCM). 

Keywords: macro-structure of the implants, bone density, computed tomography, 

histomorphometry. 

 

Introduction 

The primary stability of implants remains the key point to accomplishing successful results 

in the long term. (Cunha et al., 2014). This stability can be defined as the close contact between 

the implant and the surrounding bone (Branemark et al., 1977; Albrektssonetal, 1981; Trisi et al., 

2009; Bayarchimeg et al., 2013; Anil et al., 2015; Wang et al. 2015). In order for it to occur, it is 

necessary that micromotion rates are kept from 50 to 100 ?m. In case these rates overcome 100 

?m, fibrous capsules might be formed in the implant-bone interface causing damages to the desired 

osseointegration (Szmukler-Moncleretal, 1998; Elias et al., 2012; Cohen et al., 2015). 

Consequently the primary stability is seen as a prerequisite for favorable arrangements of implants 

with immediate loading (Hsu et al., 2013; Ryu et al., 2014).    

The close adaptation of the bone and implant is important to allow undisturbed healing and 

occurrence of bone formation, thus, permitting optimal stress distribution from masticatory 

functional loading (Eraslan and Inan, 2010). During the initial healing of an immediately loaded 

implant, the implant and bone are merely in contact, with primary stability being determined 

largely by the contact area between the bone and the implant (Hsu et al., 2013). The success of this 

initial stability is achieved by reconciling specific determinants such as the quality and quantity of 



115 

 

the host bone, surgical technique, and implant design (length, diameter and shape, i.e., the implant 

macro-structure) (Blanco et al., 2011; Freitas et al., 2012; Anil et al; 2015; Wang et al., 2015). The 

interaction between the implant and the bone determines the implant initial stability, considering 

as the main parameters the bone quality and quantity and the macro-structure of the implants 

(Wang et al., 2015; Anil et al; 2015).  

A major factor for achieving and maintaining the success of oral implants is the quality and 

quantity of the bone in the receptor site (Dantas et al., 2015). The most popular method of bone 

quality assessment is the one developed by Leckholm & Zarb (1985), who introduced a scale of I 

- IV, based on both the radiographic assessment and the sensation of resistance experienced by the 

surgeon when preparing the fixture site (Lekholm & Zarb et al., 1985; Howashi et al., 2016). 

Placing implants from bones type I (formed of homogenous cortical bone, high density bone) to 

type III (formed of a thin layer of cortical bone that surrounds a dense trabecular bone of favorable 

strength) leads to good clinical outcomes whereas bone type IV (formed of a thin layer of cortical 

bone that surrounds a low density trabecular bone) is linked to a lower success rate due to the lack 

of adequate primary stability of the implant in order to attain successful osseointegration (Martinez 

et al., 2001). Type IV bone is commonly found in posterior areas of the jaws (Lekholm & Zarb et 

al, 1985; Park et al; 2009). 

Thin cortical and trabecular bones of low density characterize the posterior region of the 

maxilla (Ahn et al., 2012). Low density bones have been pointed out as the greatest potential risk 

factors for implant loss (Anil et al., 2015). Clinical studies with consecutively placed implants that 

were immediately loaded showed a higher failure rate in low density bone, reinforcing that primary 

stability is a major determinant in the success of immediately loaded implants (Molly et al., 2006; 

Ahn et al., 2012; Anil et al., 2015). The site-specific structural and mechanical properties of bone 

tissue can exhibit great variations, the thickness of the cortical bone, the density of the cancellous 

bone, the bone mineral content,  and the histomorphometric bone-implant contact  might affect 

primary stability (Chen et al., 2008; Cha et al., 2010; Çehreli et al. 2012). 

Other important factors for a successful primary stability are the macrostructure and threads 

design of the implants (Cheng et al., 2010). Consequently, various implant designs have been 

proposed to improve long-term prognoses and to achieve better initial primary stability whenever 

poor quality bone with a thin cortical layer and cancellous bone is the selected implant site (Koticha 

et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2015). Studies found that the implant shape was an important determinant 



116 

 

of stress distribution and having a more pronounced effect than implant length or diameter (Eraslan 

and Inan, 2010; Hsu et al., 2013; Ryu et al., 2014). As for the bone surrounding the implant 

compaction, it has been noticed that tapered implants provide a greater bone compaction and a 

better force distribution if compared to parallel-walled implants. (O’Sullivan  et al., 2004; Chong 

et al., 2009; Aleo et al., 2012;  Wu et al., 2012; Dantas et al., 2015; Lozano-Carrascal et al., 2016).  

Previous studies have reported that the total contact area between the implant and bone 

plays a significant role in the bone compaction and masticatory stress distribution, and this area is 

influenced by implant thread pitch, depth, and width (Eraslan and Inan, 2010; Lan et al., 2012; 

Ryu et al., 2014). Hence, manufacturers have developed alternative structures of implants with 

different thread conformations, emphasizing the importance of improving the functional surface 

area to maximized bone implant contact and promoting a more favorable dissipation of masticatory 

tensions and bone condensation (Eraslan and Inan, 2010; Herekar et al., 2014; Javed et al., 2013; 

Ryu et al., 2014). Lan et al. (2012) reported that a square thread shape have a better bone–implant 

contact  and stress distribution in the surrounding bone compared with the V-shaped threads. 

Some qualitative and objective methods have been introduced to measure the initial 

stability when the implants are inserted. The measurement methods include noninvasive clinical 

test methods (ie, insertion torque, radiographs and resonance frequency measurement) and 

invasive research test methods (ie, Pull Out Test) (Wu et al., 2012; Ahn et al., 2012; Aleo et al., 

2012; Wang et al., 2015; Yamaguchi et al., 2015). Initial implant stability is often based on torque 

resistance measurements, which have been shown to reflect bone density, at implant placement. 

An insertion torque value from 30 to 40 N.cm before the implant is finally seated is considered 

sufficient to indicate stability (Östman et al., 2010; Oliscovicz et al., 2012; Yamaguchi et al., 

2015). Friberg et al., (1995) demonstrated that insertion torque was correlated to bone-implant 

contact (histomorphometrically assessed). Other authors, however, were not able to reproduce the 

correlation between insertion torque and histologic bone-implant contact (Nkenke et al., 2003; 

Degidi et al., 2009; Jun et al., 2010).  

Until present days, quantitative histological techniques have been considered the “golden 

standard” to evaluate the bone structure (Lespessailles et al., 2006; Arlot et al, 2008; Nogueira et 

al., 2010). Furthermore, these analyzes provide unique information about the cellularity and the 

dynamic indices of bone remodeling. Nevertheless this technique has limitations, such as clinical 

invasibility and the bone microarchitecture evaluation due to the fact that structure parameters are 



117 

 

limited to two-dimensional analysis (2D) (Bouxsein et al., 2010). Previous studies have found a 

correlation between the insertion torque value and bone-implant contact (BIC) based on 2D 

histomorphometric evaluations. Theoretically, the BIC area affects the implant stability, and the 

larger the amount of bone in contact with the implant, the higher the structural stiffness is, which 

results in higher interfacial strength (Liu et al., 2012; Cohen et al., 2015; Gramanzin et al., 2016). 

In addition, Javed et al. (2013) reported that the implant stability tends to increase with the 

maximization of bone contact. Therefore, the precise relationship of BIC with primary implant 

stability is worthy of detailed investigation. 

With the advancement of technology it has been seen the need to quantify bone density in 

the region where the dental implants would be inserted, so computerized tomography (CT) was 

introduced in implant therapy  therefore allowing a tridimensional visualization of bone (Schwarz 

et al. 1987a, 1987b). Misch 18 used computerized tomography (CT) to objectively classify bone 

density into five types based on Hounsfield units (HU). This classification makes an objective and 

precise assessment of bone quality possible. Thus, CT has been used for the objective 

quantification of the bone mineral density (González-García et al., 2012; Hawashi et al., 2016). 

Micro-computerized tomography (micro-CT) is now widely used to observe and analyze 

the internal structure of hard tissue because it is rapid, reproducible, and nondestructive (Hsu et 

al., 2013; Cunha et al., 2015). Micro-CT enables the study of structures of a few micrometers such 

as bone trabecules. Measurements can be performed within a much shorter period than the typical 

histological analysis of histomorphometric parameters and allows the use of undecalcified bone 

sample (Bouxsein et al., 2010; Kasseck et al., 2010; Lussani et al., 2015). Evidences from previous 

studies have shown that cortical and trabecular bones significantly contribute to the primary 

stability of the implants, showing that bone morphometry assessed by micro-CT is a reliable 

method to evaluate bone tissue mechanics (Cunha et al., 2015; Howashi et al., 2016). It is possible 

to establish the correlation between bone architecture and structural properties of the implants to 

enhance the mechanical performance (González-García et al., 2012; Cunha et al., 2015). 

The purpose of the present study is to determine the relation between the 

histomorphometric bone–implant contact and the initial stability of five different implant designs 

placed in controlled bone variability. 

 

Materials and Methods 



118 

 

Preparation of Bone Cylinders 

Fresh porcine bone was used in this study. Using an especially designed trephine burr, 

osteotomy was conducted and 50 bone cylinders with 15 mm in diameter and 18 mm in length 

were prepared from porcine bone, removed from the mandibular condyle (25 cylinders, low-

density bone) or from the femur head (25 cylinders, high-density bone). The samples were kept 

frozen and stored at -20°C until performing the experiments (Figure 2). 

 

Implant Selection 

50 implants of five different types, 10 of each, were used for this study. Group 1: Xive® 

Plus implant with 3.4mm in diameter and 9.5mm in length (Dentsply Friadent, GmbH, Mannheim, 

German); Group 2: Ankylos® implant with 3.5mm in diameter and 9.5mm in length (Dentsply 

Friadent, GmbH, Mannheim, German); Group 3: Straumann Bone Level implant with 3.3mm in 

diameter and 10mm in length (Straumann, Basel, Swiss); Group 4: Neodent Alvim CM implant 

with 3.5mm in diameter and 10mm in length (Neodent, Curitiba, Brazil) and Group 5: Neodent 

Drive CM implant with 3.5mm in diameter and 10mm in length (Neodent, Curitiba, Brazil) (Figure 

2). 

 

Experimental Procedures of Bone Cylinders 

The entire bone density standardization process was performed according to the protocol 

set by Dantas et al., 2015. 

Standardization of Bone Cylinders - Two-Dimensional Radiographic Analysis (2D 

analysis). 

Bone cylinders were prepared from porcine bone and divided into 2 groups: Group A, 

cylinders removed from the femur head (high bone density); and Group B, cylinders removed from 

the mandibular condyle (low bone density). Digital radiographs were taken from each cylinder, 

using a digital sensor (RVG Trophy, Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, NY, USA) and the 

images had the gray levels calibrated with the use of specific software. Then, the radiographic 

density values were obtained by measuring the gray value of the pixels using the histogram 

command. Three standardized regions of interest (ROIs), which corresponded to 16 square pixels, 

were defined for each cylinder and all of them were situated in the central portion of the 

radiographic image: one coronal, one central and one apical. The radiographic density of each ROI 



119 

 

was calculated and the average of the three ROIs was assumed as the 2D radiographic density of 

the bone cylinder. 

The cylinders were then grouped according to their 2D bone densities values: cylinders 

with values equal or greater than 110 were selected for Group A (high density bone), and with 

values equal or lower than 80 were selected for Group B (low density bone). All cylinders from 

Group A were originated from the femur head, and all from group B had origin in the mandible 

condyle. The cylinders with intermediate values were discharged, and at the end of this process, 

there were 50 bone cylinders left, 25 from group A and 25 from group B.  

 

Standardization of Bone Cylinders -Three-Dimensional Radiographic Analysis (3D 

analysis). 

Micro-CT scans of each bone cylinder were made for the evaluation of tomographic bone 

parameters. Three-dimensional analysis was performed using the Micro-Sky Scan 1172-160 

(SkyScan, Kontich, Belgium). After image reconstruction, from the center of the bone cylinder, a 

tomographic cylinder measuring 7 mm in diameter and 5 mm in height, starting 2 mm below the 

top of the bone cylinder was defined, and Three-dimensional Bone Density (BV/TV, i.e., bone 

volume/total volume) was measured (Figure 3). 

 

Insertion of implants  

The bone cylinders were fixed in a specially designed basis to immobilize them, and the 

site was prepared with progressive drilling sequence at 800 rpm following the protocol the 

manufacturer recommends (Xive® e Ankylos® - Dentsply Friadent; Bone Level – Straumann; 

AlvimCM e DriveCM – Neodent) (Figure 5).  

After site preparation, the implants were inserted into the bone cylinders (one implant in 

each cylinder) following a specific order, in which 10 implants were used for each group (from 

Group 1 to Group 5) in each experiment. Group 1 (G1): Xive Plus implants placed in high-density 

bone cylinders (n=5 implants) and Xive Plus implants placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 

implants). Group 2 (G2): Ankylos implants placed in high-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants) 

and Ankylos implants placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants). Group 3 (G3): Bone 

Level implants placed in high-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants) and Bone Level implants 

placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants). Group 4 (G4): AlvimCM implants placed in 



120 

 

high-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants) and AlvimCM implants placed in low-density bone 

cylinders (n=5 implants). Group 5 (G5): DriveCM implants placed in high-density bone cylinders 

(n=5 implants) and DriveCM implants placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants). 

Tomography after implant placement 

After installation of the implants new Micro-CT scans and micro-tomographic 

reconstructions of the cylinders were performed. Using the analysis software (CTan Analyser) to 

quantify microstructures, the volume region of interest (VOI) was determined for 3D 

morphometric analysis. In order for it to occur, four new volumetric evaluation levels were 

determined in the bone cylinders (from Level 1 to Level 4). Level 1 post-implant: Morphometric 

analysis in the first area, corresponding to the bone volume internal to the threads. Level 2 post-

implant: Morphometric analysis in the second area (0 to 0.5 mm from the end of threads) 

corresponding to the bone immediately adjacent to the end of the threads up to 0.5 mm. Level 3 

post-implant: Morphometric analysis in the third area (0.5 to 1.5 mm from the end of threads), 

corresponding to the bone volume 0.5 mm to 1.5 mm distant to the end of the threads. Level 4 

post-implant: Morphometric analysis in the fourth area (0 to 0.5 mm from the apical end of the 

implant), corresponding to the bone immediately adjacent to the apical end of the implant up to 

0.5mm (Figure 6). For all the evaluation levels, the same tomographic parameters previously 

described were analyzed (Figure 7). 

 

Histological processing and Histomorphometric analysis 

After the micro-CT analysis, bone cylinders are prepared for histomorphometric analysis. 

Each specimen was dissected and fixed in 4% phosphate-buffered formalin pH 7 for 10 days and 

transferred to a solution of 70% ethanol until processing. The specimens were dehydrated in 

increasing concentrations of alcohol up to 100%, infiltrated and embedded in methylmethacrylate 

resin LR White (London Resin Company, Berkshire, England), and hard-sectioned using the 

technique described by Donath & Breuner (1982). The sections were prepared for 

histomorphometry and stained with Stevenel´s blue and Alizarin red S for optic microscopic 

analysis.  

Histomorphometry 

Longitudinal histological sections 80-100µm from each implant were captured through a 

video camera Leica DC 300F (Leica Microsystems GmbH, Nussloch, Germany) joined to a 



121 

 

stereomicroscope Leica MZFL III (Leica Microsystems GmbH, Nussloch, Germany). The images 

were analyzed through the Image J program (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, USA) and 

the percentages of density around implants and apically to the implants were determined. 

The bone density was determined as the percentage of bone found within 4 squares 

measuring 0.5mm2 each placed in the same regions where the percentages of MicroCT were 

measured. Three squares were placed from the first peak threads corresponding to levels 1, 2 and 

3 (level 1: corresponding to the bone volume internal to the threads; level 2: the bone volume 

adjacent to the implant surface and level 3: placed in a mirror image of the second corresponding 

to the bone volume distant area) and one square was placed immediately adjacent to the apical end 

of the implant corresponding to level 4 (volume of the apical bone to the implant). With the images 

the percentages of bone-implant contact (BIC) were also determined.  

The regions of trabecula bone-implant contact (BIC) along the implant perimeter were 

subtracted from the total implant perimeter and calculations were performed to determine the BIC. 

The bone area in close contact with the threads was measured by means of computer software 

(Image J program). The areas occupied by bone were subtracted from the implant total area and 

calculations were performed to determine the trabecula bone-implant contact (reported in 

percentage values of bone area) (Figure 7). 

 

Statistical analysis 

The Anova One Way Subtest Bonferronitest was used for intra and between-groups 

comparisons for three-dimensional analysis and BIC. The Kruskal Wallis test for was used for 

comparisons intra and between groups for the histomorphometry 

 

Results 

Standardization Analysis (2D and 3D analyses) 

Two- and three-dimensional analyses prior to implant insertion in the bone cylinders were 

performed for bone bases standardization. The 2D analysis mean of the gray-level values were 

114,64 ± 7,65 for Group A and 79,56 ± 5,61 for Group B, statistically significant differences. In 

the three-dimensional bone density (TBD), the values were 27,00 ± 1,28 for Group A and 16,22 ± 

2,15 for Group B, also presenting statistical differences (Student’s t test).

Discussion 

Histomorphometry is one of the methods used to evaluate the cortical and trabecular bone 

architecture, enabling a safe qualification and quantification of bone structures, such technique has 

long been classified as “gold standard” (Nogueira et al., 2010; Bouxsein et al., 2010; Kang et al., 

2016). In this study, after histological preparation, each implant image was captured from pre-



130 

 

prepared plates.  Four levels for histomorphometric analysis were determined from the image 

capture: Level 1) Bone density between threads; Level 2) Bone density of the areas immediately 

adjacent to the threads; Level 3) Bone density distant to the implants and Level 4) Bone density 

apical to the implant. The bone-implant contact (BIC) percentages were also determined. As for 

the bone-density analysis, the trabecular bone and marrow space percentages were evaluated for 

the areas investigated. A greater percentage of trabecular bone was found between the threads 

(L1), when compared to the areas distant to the threads (L3) and apical to the implant (L4), for all 

the high-density groups, with statistically significant differences in groups G2, G3, G4 and G5. In 

the area immediately adjacent to the threads (L2), numerical values slightly lower than in N1 were 

observed, thus, exhibiting a bone condensation growth caused by the implant design during its 

insertion, improving bone density between threads in the immediately adjacent areas. 

Consequently, promoting a greater initial stability, thus, corroborating Hsu et al, 2013’s postulate. 

Regarding the findings in N3, probably this bone condensation growth does not reach these areas, 

not affecting the trabecular bones at distance. In the low-density bone, there was also a tendency 

to numeral decrease, yet, more gradual than in the high-density bone basis, and these results were 

more evident in the comparison between L4 (apical) and L1 (intra-thread). In addition, in G1, G4 

and G5, there were greater density values, in the area immediately adjacent to the threads (L2), 

when compared to the values between threads (L1). Also, in G1, both in high and low densities, 

this numerical increase was observed in N2. This was probably due to a trabecular bone disruption 

that might have occurred, in the low-density bone, during the last drilling followed by implant 

placement, leading to lesser intra-thread area compaction. 

In theory, implant stability is affected by the bone-implant contact area (BIC). The greater 

the bone-to-implant contact, the greater the stability, thus, resulting in higher resistance in this 

interface (Liu et al., 2012). The varied implant design modifications are designed to increase the 

bone-implant contact area (Lozano-Carrascal et al., 2016). In this study, G2, both in high and low 

densities, presented more results, numerically and statistically, for bone-implant contact area. 

Studies have shown a correlation between thread quantity and depth with variables that affect and 

maximize the bone-implant contact (Inceoglu et al., 2009; Oliscovicz et al., 2012). According to 

other studies, implants with shallower tapers and less space between them may interfere in primary 

stability assessed by means of IT (Bezerra et al., 2010; Rocha et al., 2010). In G4, the lowest bone-

implant contact values were observed, in both bone bases; such findings do not corroborate the 



131 

 

mechanical tests results, for both G4 and G5 presented the highest IT and RFA values, in the tests 

in porcine bone, when compared to the other groups. Hence, the histomorphometric analysis two-

dimensional plan might not be sufficiently accurate to assess the implant three-dimensional 

situation in the bone basis. 

The use of high-resolution images obtained by means of computed microtomography 

(Micro-CT) to evaluate the morphology of the trabecular and cortical bones in animals and humans 

has grown vastly. It is a nondestructive technique that reconstructs samples in the 

microtomographic scale and obtains information on their three-dimensional geometry and material 

properties (Bouxsein et al., 2010; Lussani et al., 2015). In this study, the three-dimensional 

tomographic evaluation was performed in four different bone levels (bone in the area between 

threads, immediately adjacent to the threads, at a distance of approximately 0.5-1.5 mm from them 

and apical to the implant), and at two moments (post- and pre-implant insertion), aiming at 

evaluating the effect of the insertion of five implant types in high- and low-densities bone bases.  

The assessment of the post- and pre-implant insertion differences in the three-dimensional 

bone density (BV/TV) parameter showed a greater condensation between threads (N1), when 

compared to the area distant to the threads (N3), for all the groups in both bone densities. The 

analysis between groups revealed that all the implants inserted in the low-density bone bases had 

a greater percentage of condensation (increase in BV/TV), numerically and statistically, than the 

implants inserted in high density. This effect was more evident in N1, and there was a tendency to 

reduction in condensation up to N3. Similar results were also observed regarding the reductions in 

the tomographic parameter of Trabecular Separation (Tb.Sp). These results corroborate the 

findings by Karg et al., 2016. When analyzing the relation between primary stability and the 

structural parameters of the trabecular bone by means of computed tomography (CBCT), they 

observed a positive correlation to structural parameters of the trabecular bone (BV/TV, BV, BS, 

BSD, Tb.Th, Tb.N, FD e BS/BV) (p<0,01), and negative correlations to other microstructural 

parameters (Tb.Sp, Tb.Pf e SMI). Their results are also in consistency with the findings by Dantas 

et al., 2015, who during the evaluation of the same structural parameters in the current study, 

observed the same tendency to condensation in the two correlated parameters (evidenced by the 

increase in BV/TV and the decrease in Th.Sp). The assessment of the post- and pre-implant 

insertion differences in the total porosity parameter showed that for the increase in the post-implant 

insertion condensation, there was a decrease in Total Porosity (Po.Tot). Thus, for this parameter, 



132 

 

groups G4 and G5 presented the highest post-implant insertion reductions, in both high- and low-

density bone bases. 

The microtomographic parameter analysis presented an influence of the implants in the 

modification of the bone structure up to level 2 of evaluation, (up to 0.5 mm distance of the thread 

tips), resulting in increase of bone condensation, and decrease of trabecular separation and 

porosity. The analysis of the bone areas that are more distant to the implant (N3) revealed a low 

bone condensation growth when compared to the other levels (N1, N2 e N4). In addition, there 

was an increase of bone density in the apical area (N4), which might be due to the implant-bed 

preparation technique, for the compression of the bone structure caused by the implant axial 

movement. This finding might be especially important to implants inserted in low-density bone 

bases: the compression of the apical bone might aid during implant placement, increasing the initial 

stability. Blitz et al., 2010, used a study in tibia of rats to show that it is possible to visualize and 

quantify the porosity of the cortical bone in rats by means of Micro-CT. The authors were able to 

validate their results by means of comparison to the conventional histologic analysis. This study 

corroborates this finding in literature, by observing the relation between conventional 2D 

histomorphometry  and 3D analysis through Micro-CT, especially for the BV/TV, Tb.SP, Po.Cl, 

Po.Op and Po.Tot parameters.  

Although implant primary stability has been widely investigated regarding trabecular bone 

density and cortical bone thickness, few studies have investigated the relation between implant 

stability and trabecular bone microstructure (Kang et al., 2016). Some studies have shown a 

correlation between IT during implant placement, bone-implant contact (BIC) and bone quality 

(Liu et al., 2012; Cunha et al., 2014). Bone density, according to CT, CBTC and Micro-CT, 

presented significant correlation to IT and RFA values (Turkyilmaz et al., 2011; Isoda et al., 2012). 

The greater the CBTC value, the higher the maximum pullout strength (Meira et al., 2013). A 

correlation between RFA and TI and morphological parameters were also observed (Howashi, et 

al., 2015). Yet, Kang et al., 2015, revealed no correlation between these parameters, claiming that 

the RFA does not seem appropriate as a sole evaluation method of primary stability. The 

biomechanical and image analyses (subtraction, histologic and microtomographic) in this study 

presented consistent results and were better in Group 4 (implant Alvim CM) and Group 5 (implant 

Drive CM), in both bone bases. The histologic results confirmed the results obtained by means of 

computed microtomography analysis, thus, validating the image analysis method. 



133 

 

As a result, according to the results for all the parameters evaluated post- and pre-implant 

insertion, by means of MicroCT, there were statistically significant differences mainly for G4 

(AlvimCM) and G5 (DriveCM) when compared to the other groups. The histomorphometric 

analysis presented higher values of bone compaction and Bone-implant contact (BIC) for G2 

(Ankylos), G4 (AlvimCM) and G5 (DriveCM).

Mechanical assessment of primary stability of five different implants inserted in 

standardized artificial bone bases.

Abstract 

Primary stability is associated with the mechanical engagement of an implant with the 

surrounding bone. The aim of this study was to evaluate the primary stability of five different 

implants inserted in standardized bone bases of porcine bone and polyurethane blocks (in vitro 

models), by means of mechanical tests and image analysis (subtraction). For the analyses in the 

polyurethane blocks, 50 high- and low-density blocks (D1 and D3, respectively) were sectioned, 

and 50 implants were inserted individually in the blocks, using ten of each, then were divided in 

five groups: Group 6 (G6): Xive Plus implants inserted in high-density polyurethane blocks - D1 

(n=5) and in low-density blocks - D3 (n=5); Group 7 (G7): Ankylos implants inserted in high-

density polyurethane blocks - D1 (n=5) and in low-density blocks - D3 (n=5); Group 8 (G8): Bone 

Level implants inserted in high-density polyurethane blocks - D1 (n=5) and in low-density blocks 

http://www.perioforp.com.br/ptBR/scombati@forp.usp.br


142 

 

- D3 (n=5); Group 9 (G9): AlvimCM implants inserted in high-density polyurethane blocks - D1 

(n=5) and in low-density blocks- D3 (n=5); Group 9 (G9): DriveCM implants inserted in high-

density polyurethane blocks - D1 (n=5) and in low-density blocks - D3 (n=5). After implant 

insertion, they were analyzed as to insertion torque (IT), resonance frequency (RFA) and by means 

of pullout strength test (PS). According to image methods, AlvimCM and DriveCM implants 

presented the best results in the mechanical tests, and concerning the increase of bone density 

surrounding the implant. 

Keywords: macro-structure of the implants, bone density, biomechanical test. 

 

Introduction 

Primary stability following implant placement is an essential condition for 

osseointegration, especially when early or immediate loading protocols are considered as treatment 

modalities in dental implantology (Ahn et al., 2012; Ryu et al., 2014). Primary stability is 

associated with the mechanical engagement of an implant with the surrounding bone (Javed et al., 

2013; Anil et al., 2015; Wang et al. 2015). This imbrication is crucial to assure the resistance of 

the implant to micromovements, thus it may lead to fibrous encapsulation of the implant once a 

threshold displacement of 50-150µm is surpassed (Szmukler-Moncleretal, 1998; Elias et al., 2012; 

Karl et al., 2015). 

It is important for the implant to have appropriate stability in order to supply undisturbed 

healing and bone formation, thereby allowing optimal stress distribution from masticatory and 

occlusal functional loads (Eraslan and Inan, 2010). However, this stability process may be affected 

by many factors, including the quantity and density of bone available at the implant site 

(Alghamadi et al., 2011; Wang et al., 2015; Anil et al., 2015), implant design (length, diameter 

and shape, i.e., the implant macro-structure) (Chong et al., 2009; Koticha et al., 2012; Elias et al., 

2012) and by the surgical technique (e.g., the relation between drilling and implant sizes) (Kim et 

al., 2011).  

The most important parameters for the initial stability are the quality and quantity of the 

bone as well as the macro-structure of the implants (Wang et al., 2015; Anil et al; 2015). In implant 

dentistry, the most accepted classification of bone quality has been the one proposed by Lekholm 

& Zarb (1985), based on both the amount of cortical and trabecular bone shown in preoperative 

radiographs and the sensation of resistance experienced by the surgeon when preparing the fixture 



143 

 

site generating four scores (I-IV). Using this system, the surgeon grades the bone from type 1 (high 

density bone) to type 4 (low density bone) the way it feels during drilling (Lekholm & Zarb et al., 

1985; Marquezan et al., 2012; Hawashi et al., 2016).  

The effective bond between an implant and its surrounding bone is created by various 

mechanical factors. The macrostructure and threads design of the implants are some of these key 

factors since they determine the primary stability and stress distribution during osseointegration 

(Çehreli et al., 2012; Ruy et al., 2014). Nowadays, manufacturers produce dental implants in order 

to guarantee and provide good primary stability even with poor bone quality (Aleo et al., 2012; 

Wu et al., 2012; Yamaguchi et al., 2015; Lozano-Carrascal et al., 2016). The design of an implant 

plays an essential role in the osseointegration process, particularly in low-density bone (Chong et 

al., 2009; Wu et al., 2012; Jimbo et al., 2014). Studies have consistently reported that the initial 

stability in the tapared implant is significantly higher than that for the cylindrical one (Koticha et 

al., 2012; Dantas et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2015; Lozano-Carrascal et al., 2016). This may be due 

to the compression provided by tapered implants on the cortical bone and the balanced distribution 

of forces into the surrounding bone. When inserted it creates a lateral compaction of the bone 

particularly in a poor bone implant site (Bilhan et al., 2010; Dos Santos et al., 2011; Ruy et al., 

2014; Lozano-Carrascal et al., 2016). 

In order to maximize the surface area available for contact and improve mechanical 

anchorage and primary stability in cancellous bone (Orsini et al., 2012), threads have been 

incorporated into implants to improve initial stability (Wu et al., 2012; Chang et al., 2012), enlarge 

implant surface area, and distribute stress favorably (Eraslan and Inan, 2010). Recent studies have 

focused on the influence and sensitivity of the implant features, such as thread pitch, depth, width 

and angle. Understanding these factors and applying them appropriately to the design of dental 

implants could help reduce the potential for implant failure (Abuhussein et al., 2010; Wu et al., 

2012; Gehrke et al., 2015). Studies evaluating the stability of implants with different thread designs 

(trapezoidal, buttress, square, and standard V-thread) observed that implants with square thread 

profile were more stable in comparison to other designs, which may happen due to the increased 

bone condensation these square threads promote (Rokn etal., 2011; Ahn et al., 2012; Chang et al., 

2012; Koticha et al., 2012). 

Numerous methods have been used to assess the primary stability of the dental implant. 

They include biomechanical tests, which are measured by noninvasive and invasive tests. 



144 

 

Noninvasive tests (such as Insertion Torque and Resonance Frequency Analysis) are clinically 

relevant to assess implant stability during surgery whereas invasive test methods (ie, Pull-out) 

evaluate the stability of the implant more precisely (Wu et al., 2012; Ahn et al., 2012; Aleo et al., 

2012; Wang et al., 2015; Yamaguchi et al., 2015). The insertion torque measured through surgical 

hand-pieces during implant placement provides real-time feedback that can be used to predict 

implant survival and to estimate healing time before loading (Walker et al., 2011; Elias et al., 

2012). Some authors have found that insertion torque values above 32 N.cm are an indication of 

adequate primary stability (Dos Santos et al., 2011; Lozano-Carrascal et al., 2016). The amount of 

insertion torque is based on density of the bone and macro-design of the implant (Çehreli et al., 

2012). The resonance frequency analysis (RFA) measures implant-bone interface through the 

reaction to oscillations exerted to the implant. The result is expressed as the implant stability 

quotient (ISQ), units ranging from 0 to 100, with higher values implying greater stability (Meredith 

et al., 1999; Wang et al., 2015; Anil et al., 2015). The value produced is a combination of bone 

implant contact and bone density around the implants (Wang et al., 2015; Lozano-Carrascal et al., 

2016). 

One method for evaluating the biomechanical performance of implants is the axial pull-out 

test. It verifies the maximum pull-out strength of implants inserted in bone samples. The greater 

the strength is, the larger the bone-implant contact and consequently the larger the primary stability 

(Lima et al., 2010; Barbosa et al., 2012; Oliscovicz et al., 2013). The resistance to pulling out the 

screws is multifactorial and is related to the bone density, with the implant design and the 

preparation of the bone site. Studies have shown the correlation between insertion torque (IT), 

resonance frequency (RF) and axial pullout strength (PS), determining that the greater the 

resistance greater bone-implant contact (Oliscovicz et al., 2013; Dantas et al., 2015; Wang et al., 

2015). 

There is therefore enough evidence that the primary stability is strongly affected by the 

bone quality and the implant macrostructure. This is the reason why numerous manufactures have 

been releasing implants for areas of low bone quality. The aim of this in vitro study was to evaluate 

the primary stability through biomechanical tests and image subtraction in five different implants 

designs placed in artificial as well as standardized porcine bones blocks, with high and low density. 

 

Materials and Methods 



145 

 

For this study were used fresh porcine bones, acquired from slaughterhouses of Ribeirão 

Preto -SP and region, as well as artificial bones (polyurethane blocks). 

Implant Selection 

100 implants of five different types (20 of each) were used for this study. The experiments 

were primarily divided into 5 groups: Group I - Xive® Plus implant with 3.4mm in diameter and 

9.5mm in length (Dentsply Friadent, GmbH, Mannheim, German); Group II - Ankylos® implant 

with 3.5mm in diameter and 9.5mm in length (Dentsply Friadent, GmbH, Mannheim, German); 

Group III - Straumann Bone Level implant with 3.3mm in diameter and 10mm in length 

(Straumann, Basel, Swiss); Group IV - Neodent Alvim CM implant with 3.5mm in diameter and 

10mm in length (Neodent, Curitiba, Brazil) and Group V - Neodent Drive CM implant with 3.5mm 

in diameter and 10mm in length (Neodent, Curitiba, Brazil) (Figure 1). 

50 implants were inserted on the porcine bones and the other 50 were inserted in the 

polyurethane blocks. All of them have gone through common steps: preparation, insertion, 

mechanical tests and evaluation. Obviously, in order for these steps to be performed, both the 

porcine and the artificial bones’ characteristics have been taken into account.  

Preparation of Bone Cylinders 

Fresh porcine bone was used in this study. Using an especially designed trephine burr, 

osteotomy was conducted and 50 bone cylinders with 15 mm in diameter and 18 mm in length 

were prepared from porcine bone, removed from the mandibular condyle (25 cylinders, low-

density bone) or from the femur head (25 cylinders, high-density bone). The samples were kept 

frozen and stored at -20°C until performing the experiments (Figure 2). The entire bone density 

standardization process was performed according to the protocol set by Dantas et al., 2015. 

 

Insertion of implants  

The bone cylinders were fixed in a specially designed basis to immobilize them, and the 

site was prepared with progressive drilling sequence at 800 rpm following the protocol the 

manufacturer recommends (Xive® e Ankylos® - Dentsply Friadent; Bone Level – Straumann; 

AlvimCM e DriveCM – Neodent) (Figure 5).  

After site preparation, the implants were inserted into the bone cylinders (one implant in 

each cylinder) following a specific order, in which 10 implants were used for each group (from 

Group 1 to Group 5) in each experiment. Group 1 (G1): Xive Plus implants placed in high-density 



146 

 

bone cylinders (n=5 implants) and Xive Plus implants placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 

implants). Group 2 (G2): Ankylos implants placed in high-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants) 

and Ankylos implants placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants). Group 3 (G3): Bone 

Level implants placed in high-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants) and Bone Level implants 

placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants). Group 4 (G4): Alvim CM implants placed in 

high-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants) and Alvim CM implants placed in low-density bone 

cylinders (n=5 implants). Group 5 (G5): Drive CM implants placed in high-density bone cylinders 

(n=5 implants) and Drive CM implants placed in low-density bone cylinders (n=5 implants). 

 

Implants Insertion Torque 

As for the implants insertion it was used the IChiropro motor, which has a torque and speed 

electronic control, which are shown in real time, during the implants insertion, through a tablet 

(IPad) and automatically storing the data in a file.   

A contra-angle 20:1 was also attached to the motor with internal irrigation and LED 

lightning for the insertion of the implants in the bone cylinders. All insertions were initiated with 

a 10 N.cm torque until reaching their completeness and were interrupted at the exact moment when 

the implant was totally inserted and positioned to the bone level. The last registered value was 

considered the insertion torque of each implant (Figure 6).    

 

Resonance Frequency Analysis (RFA) 

Once installation was complete, the implants were subjected to resonance frequency 

analysis (RFA), which was represented in a quantitative scale from 1 to 100. The interpretation of 

these values yields the implant stability quotient (ISQ). The stability of each implant was 

mensurated using the Osstell® Mentor (Osstell AB, Göteborg, Sweden). This device uses a wireless 

transducer with a magnetic post (Smartpeg type 16; Osstell AB) connected to the implant. The 

measurements were performed in four different perpendicular directions of the implant, with 90 

degrees intervals among them, and the values were selected to determine the final ISQ of each 

implant, as indicated by the manufacturer (Figure 7). 

Preparation of Artificial Bone 

In this study, we used homogeneous artificial model-based polyurethane, which has 

uniform elastic property (isotropic) and modulated elasticity similar to human bone marrow. This 



147 

 

material is appropriate for studies aimed at simulating human bone - polyurethane is considered 

the standard material for the mechanical testing of orthopedic implants. Thus, 50 polyurethane 

blocks (Nacional Ossos, Jaú, Brazil) of 2 cm in length, 2 cm in height and 2 cm in width were used 

in two different densities: using the Misch bone density classification, D1 bone (high density bone 

– 25 blocks) was simulated in polyurethane blocks of 40g/cm3 (40 PCF) and D3 bone (low density 

bone – 25 blocks) was simulated in polyurethane blocks of 20g/cm3 (20 PCF). The blocks were of 

the same batch and properly weighed for its uniformity. 

 

Experimental Procedures of Artificial Blocks 

The 50 implants placed in artificial blocks (ten from each group, G6, G7, G8, G9 and G10) 

were individually inserted into the blocks following a specific order. Group 6 (G6): Xive Plus 

implants placed in D1 polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants) and Xive Plus implants placed in D3 

polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants). Group 7 (G7): Ankylos implants placed in D1 polyurethane 

blocks (n=5 implants) and Ankylos implants placed in D3 polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants). 

Group 8 (G8): Bone Level implants placed in D1 polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants) and Bone 

Level implants placed in D3 polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants). Group 9 (G9): Alvim CM 

implants placed in D1 polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants) and Alvim CM implants placed in D3 

polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants). Group 10 (G10): Drive CM implants placed in D1 

polyurethane blocks (n=5 implants) and Drive CM implants placed in D3 polyurethane blocks 

(n=5 implants) (Figure 8). 

These implants in artificial blocks were submitted to the same insertion procedures as the 

implants in porcine bone. As for the insertion torque and resonance frequency the implants placed 

in polyurethane blocks were also assessed the same way as the ones placed in bone cylinders. After 

the resonance frequency analysis, the biomechanical pull-out test was performed in each implant 

placed in the polyurethane blocks.     

Pullout test 

The main goal of this test is to evaluate the resistance force of the bone-implant interface. 

It was conducted at the Bioengineering Laboratory of the Faculty of Medicine of Ribeirão Preto, 

according to the technical standard ASTM F543. 

The 50 implants placed in individual blocks (ten from each group, G6, G7, G8, G9 and 

G10) were examined. The block with the implant was positioned in the Universal Testing Machine 



148 

 

and connected to a mobile base through a specially designed and screwed to the implant device. 

Posteriorly, a load cell of 200kg was adjusted and after a pre-load of 10N for 30 seconds, an axial 

tensile strength with constant speed of 2mm/min was applied (Figure 9). The load versus 

deformation curve was evaluated using the software Tesc 1.13: the highest value in this curve was 

considered the Pullout force. 

Statistical analysis 

The Kruskal Wallis + Dunn tests was used for between-groups comparisons for the 

averages of insertion torque, resonance frequency analysis and pullout test.  

 

Results 

Subtraction Analysis (2D analysis) 

The mean values ± standard deviation percentage variation in the subtraction analysis 

between the 2D images, before and after implant insertion, in Group 1 (G1) were 123,80 ± 11 % 

for high density and 129,00 ± 3 % for low density; in Group 2 (G2), 128,40 ± 7 % for high density 

and 135,40 ± 11 % for low density; in Group 3 (G3), 127,60 ± 12 % for high density, and 154,00 

± 11 % for low density; in Group 4 (G4), 168,40 ± 7 % for high density, and 177,20 ± 22 % for 

low density; in Group 5 (G5), 170,00 ± 21 % and 219,00 ± 19 % for high- and low-density bone 

bases, respectively. There were statistically significant differences between G1 and G5; G1 and 

G4; G2 and G4; G3 and G4 in the high-density bone cylinders; and in the low-density cylinders, 

statistical differences between G1 and G5; G2 and G5 were noted (for all the analyses, Kruskall-

Wallys test, p<0,05) (Graph 1). 

 

Biomechanical Tests 

Porcine Bone 

The mean values ± standard deviation of insertion torque (N.cm) of the implants inserted 

in Group 1 (G1) were 23,88 ± 3,95 N.cm in the high-density bone cylinders, and 18,46 ± 4,23 

N.cm in the low density; for Group 2 (G2), they were 30,52 ± 1,99 N.cm in high density, and 14,34 

± 2,68 N.cm in the low-density bone cylinders; in Group 3 (G3), they were 24,32 ± 3,60 N.cm in 

the high density and 16,24 ± 1,10 N.cm in low density; in Group 4 (G4), the implants inserted in 

the high-density cylinders presented values of 38,18 ± 2,75 N.cm, and the low density, 21 ± 9,43 

N.cm; and, in Group 5 (G5), they presented values of 47,66 ± 8,51 N.cm and 19,46 ± 2,93 N.cm, 



149 

 

in high and low density bone cylinders, respectively. There were statistically significant 

differences between groups G1 and G5, G3 and G4, G3 and G5 in high-density bone cylinders, as 

well as between groups G2 and G5, G4 and G5 in low density (for the analyses, Kruskal Wallis + 

Dunn tests, p<0.05) (Graph). 

The mean values ± standard deviation of resonance frequency (ISQ) of the implants 

inserted in Group 1 (G1) were 68,05 ± 2,13 ISQ in high-density bone cylinders and 63,70 ± 2,90 

ISQ in low density; in Group 2 (G2), they were 64,80 ± 3,88 ISQ in high density and 63,55 ± 1,38 

ISQ in low density; in Group 3(G3), it could be observed values of 64,60 ± 4,35 ISQ in the high-

density cylinders, and values of 62,25 ± 4,17 ISQ in low density; in Group 4 (G4), they were 69,75 

± 1,78 ISQ in high density, and 63,75 ± 3,02 ISQ in low density; and in Group 5 (G5), they were 

66,50 ± 2,83 ISQ in high-density cylinders, and 61,20 ± 3,18 ISQ in low density. There were 

statistically significant differences between groups G1 and G5, G3 and G4, G3 and G5 in high-

density bone cylinders, as well as between G2 and G5, G4 andG5 in low density (for the analyses, 

Kruskal Wallis + Dunn tests, p<0.05)  (Graph). 

 

Artificial Bone 

The mean values ± standard deviation of insertion torque (N.cm) of the implants inserted 

in polyurethane blocks in Group 1 (G1) were 62,78 ± 1,10 N.cm in high density, and 25,06 ± 3,12 

N.cm in low density; for Group 2 (G2), the following values could be observed 64,46 ± 4,89 N.cm 

in high-density blocks, and 21,54 ± 1,83 N.cm in low density; in Group 3 (G3), the implants
